{{Orphan|date=May 2017}}
{{Infobox scientist | name = Laura Crispini | image = LauraCrispiniXXXIPNRA.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Laura Crispini in [[Antarctica]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|5|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Genova, Italy]] | nationality = [[Italy]] | fields = [[Structural Geology]] | workplaces = [[University of Genoa]] | alma_mater = [[University of Genoa]] | website = {{URL|https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Laura_Crispini}} }}
'''Laura Crispini''' is an Italian geologist and an [[Antarctic]] researcher. Her areas of expertise are for the Tectonics, Geodynamics and Geological Mapping including the Geology of [[Antarctica]]. She has been nominated among 150 International representative of female Antarctic researchers for the SCAR "Celebration of Women in Antarctic Research" wikibomb event.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Meetup/SCAR_2016|title=SCAR Women of the Antarctic Wikibomb|last=|first=|date=|website=Wikipedia:Meetup/SCAR_2016|trans-title=SCAR Women of the Antarctic Wikibomb|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=April 2018}} At present she is Professor at the [[University of Genoa]] at the Department for Earth Sciences, Envinronment and life (DISTAV).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.distav.unige.it/drupalint|title=Dipartimento di Scienze della Terra dell'Ambiente e della Vita|last=|first=|date=|website=distav.unige.it|trans-title=Department of Earth Sciences, the Environment and Life|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-03-28}}</ref>
== Early life and education == Laura Crispini received her master's degree in Geology (1990) [[University of Genoa]], and obtained her PhD in Earth Sciences in 1995 while spending a training period in [[Structural Geology]] at the [[ETH Zurich]]. From 1996 to 1999, she was a Post-doctoral Researcher in [[Geology]] of [[Antarctica]], at the [[University of Siena]] and at [[University of Genoa]] were in 1999 she got a position as a Researcher.
== Career and impact == Laura Crispini research is on the [[Tectonics]] and [[Geodynamics]] of [[Antarctica]] and the Paleopacific margin of [[Gondwana]]. She has travelled to Antarctica six times for extended field research seasons, always working from remote field camps being the first Italian woman geologist, mapping for the international GIGAMAP project in 1996-97,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bgr.bund.de/DE/Themen/Polarforschung/Produkte/karten.html|title=BGR-GIGAMAP|last=|first=|date=|website=bgr.bund.de|publisher=Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften|trans-title=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="Carte_MNA">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mna.it/Editoria/Carte_tematiche/Carte_MNA.html|title=Geological map of Antarctica|last=|first=|date=|website=www.mna.it|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://eurekamag.com/research/018/976/018976667.php|title=GIGAMAP-Maps|}}</ref> and describing the first occurrence of native gold in the Antarctic continent in 2005-06 (Transantarctic Mountains, East Antarctica).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Global-Issues/2014/0112/Antarctica-and-the-Arctic-A-polar-primer-for-the-new-great-game/|title=Antarctica and the Arctic: A polar primer for the new great game|last=Fox|first=Douglas|date=January 12, 2014|website=www.csmonitor.com|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://antarticos.blogspot.it/2006/02/hallan-oro-en-la-antrtida.html|title=hallan-oro-en-la-antrtida|}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://geoantarctica.wordpress.com/2012/12/25/corsa-alloro/p1010404-2/|title=Gold finding Antarctica}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wsimag.com/it/scienza-e-tecnologia/19682-antartide-prezioso-forziere-della-vita/|title=Antartide Prezioso Forziere della Vita}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mercado.com.ar/notas/vida-y-estilo/40104/antrtida-un-equipo-italiano-detect-oro-en-la-tierra-de-%3Cb%3Evictor/|title=Un equipo italiano detectó oro en la tierra de Victoria}}</ref>
Crispini has been nationally and internationally recognized for her contributions to Antarctic Geoscience;<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.victoria.ac.nz/antarctic/pdf/IceSked26.pdf|title=Italy and New Zealand in Antarctica}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.victoria.ac.nz/antarctic/about/news |title=Italy and New Zealand in Antarctica 2016}}</ref> she has been working on Antarctic Geology since 1992 first with two post PhD grants funded by [[National Antarctic Research Program|PNRA]] and since 1996 she joined six Scientific Expeditions in Antarctica as Field Geologist.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uta.enea.it/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/IL-PERSONALE-IN-ANTARTIDE.pdf/|title=Enea-Il Personale in Antartide}}</ref> (XII (1996–97)-XIX (2003–04) - XXI (2005–06)-XXX (2014–15) Italian Antarctic Expeditions and the [[German Antarctic North Victoria Land Expedition]] [[GANOVEX]] XI (2015–16) and [[GANOVEX]] XII (2016–17)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bgr.bund.de/DE/Themen/Polarforschung/Projekte/Antarktis_laufend/ganovex_11.html?nn=7085334|title=BGR-GANOVEX XI}}</ref> and [[GANOVEX]] XII<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bgr.bund.de/DE/Gemeinsames/Oeffentlichkeitsarbeit/Pressemitteilungen/BGR/bgr-2016-10-17_antarktis-expedition_gondwana-station.html?nn=1542388/|title= Expedition GANOVEX XII}}</ref> - REGGAE Expedition in northern Victoria Land, working in the field from remote Field Camps,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/dlr_de/24162904423/|title=Helliwell Hills Camp, 2015-16|}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/dlr_de/24162902383/in/album-72157664272307325/|title=Helliwell Hills Camp, 2015-16|}}</ref>).
She's is Principal Investigator of the REGGAE Project, a project on the link between geophysical interpretations and field-based geological observations in [[Antarctica]] funded by [[National Antarctic Research Program|PNRA]] in collaboration with Researchers from the CNR (Pisa Italy), BGR (Germany), University of Bremen (Germany) and BAS (British Antarctic Survey) and she has been P.I. of a [[National Antarctic Research Program|PNRA]] funded Project on Geodynamics of Antarctica.<ref>https://www.researchgate.net/project/Evolution-of-the-Lanterman-Mariner-tectonic-melange-evidences-for-the-geodynamic-of-the-paleo-Pacific-margin-of-Gondwana-and-numerical-models</ref>
She is an active member of the SCAR group GEOMAP to promote the capture of existing geological map data, update its spatial reliability and enable data delivery via web feature services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scar.org/ssg/geosciences/geomap|title=SCAR GROUP GEOMAP|website=www.scar.org}}</ref>
Laura Crispini is involved in the ABYSS ITN Training Network funded by the European Commission<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://abyss-itn.eu/|title=ABYSS|last=|first=|date=|website=abyss-itn.eu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=|}}</ref> that aims at training a new generation of researchers in Geodynamics, Mineralogy, Hydrodynamics, Thermodynamics and (Bio)geochemistry focusing on mid-ocean ridge processes and their environmental and economic impacts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://searocksblog.org/2015/09/28/fieldwork-the-backstage/|title=ABYSS Fieldwork}}</ref> She worked as scientist in the ODP-IODP projects on the geology at Superfast Spreading Ridge joining scientific expeditions in the Pacific Ocean as petrologist and structural geologist (LEG 206<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/BRG/ODP/ODP/LEG_SUMM/206/leg206.html|title= ODP Leg 206: An In Situ Section of Upper Oceanic Crust Created by Superfast Seafloor Spreading Leg 206 Shipboard Scientific Party}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www-odp.tamu.edu/publications/prelim/206_prel/prel3.html#1004720|title= ODP Leg 206: Leg 206 Shipboard Scientific Party}}</ref> and Exp 309) on the [[JOIDES Resolution|Joides Resolution]] vessel.
==Selected works on Antarctica== * Capponi G., CRISPINI L. & Meccheri M. - 1999 - The metaconglomerates of the eastern Lanterman Range (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica): new constraints for their interpretation. - Antarctic Science, 11(2), 215-225........<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Capponi|first=G.|last2=Crispini|first2=L.|last3=Meccheri|first3=M.|date=1999|title=The metaconglomerates of the eastern Lanterman Range (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica): new constraints for their interpretation|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=219699&fileId=S0954102099000280|journal=Antarctic Science|language=en|volume=11|issue=2|pages=215–225|doi=10.1017/S0954102099000280}}</ref> * Capponi G., CRISPINI L. & Meccheri M. - 1999 - Structural history and tectonic evolution of the boundary between the Wilson and Bowers Terranes, Lanterman Range, Northern Victoria Land, Antarctica. - Tectonophysics, 312 (2-4), 249-266.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Capponi|first=G.|last2=Crispini|first2=L.|last3=Meccheri|first3=M.|date=1999|title=Structural history and tectonic evolution of the boundary between the Wilson and Bowers Terranes, Lanterman Range, Northern Victoria Land, Antarctica|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0040195199001742|journal=Tectonophysics|language=en|volume=312|issue=2-4|pages=249–266|doi=10.1016/S0040-1951(99)00174-2||bibcode=1999Tectp.312..249C}}</ref> * CRISPINI L. & Capponi G. - 2002 - Albitite and listvenite in the Lanterman Fault Zone (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica). In Gamble, J., Skinner, D., and Henrys, S. (Eds.), Antarctica at the close of a Millennium, Royal Society of New Zealand Bulletin 35, 113 - 119.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Crispini|first=L.|last2=Capponi|first2=G.|date=2002|title=Albitite and listvenite in the Lanterman Fault Zone (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica).In: Gamble, J., Skinner, D., and Henrys, S. (Eds.), Antarctica at the close of a Millennium|url=http://www.royalsociety.org.nz/publications/reports/annual/2002year/publishing/|journal=RSNZ Bulletin|language=en|volume=35|pages=113–119}}</ref> * Capponi G., CRISPINI L. & Meccheri M. - 2002 - Tectonic evolution at the boundary between the Wilson and Bowers Terranes (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica): structural evidence from the Mountaineer and Lanterman Range. In Gamble, J., Skinner, D., and Henrys, S. (Eds.), Antarctica at the close of a Millennium, Royal Society of New Zealand Bulletin 35, 105 - 112.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Capponi|first=G.|last2=Crispini|first2=L.|last3=Meccheri|first3=M.|date=2002|title=ectonic evolution at the boundary between the Wilson and Bowers Terranes (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica): structural evidence from the Mountaineer and Lanterman Range. In Gamble, J., Skinner, D., and Henrys, S. (Eds.), Antarctica at the close of a Millennium|url=http://www.royalsociety.org.nz/publications/reports/annual/2002year/publishing/|journal=RSNZ Bulletin|language=en|volume=35|pages=105–112}}</ref> * Federico L., Capponi G. and CRISPINI L. - 2006- The Ross orogeny of the Transantarctic Mountains: a northern Victoria Land perspective. - International Journal of Earth Sciences, DOI 10.1007/s00531-005-0063-5.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Federico|first=L.|last2=Capponi|first2=G.|last3=Crispini|first3=L.|date=2006|title=The Ross orogeny of the Transantarctic Mountains: a northern Victoria Land perspective|url=|journal=International Journal of Earth Sciences|language=en|volume=|issue=|pages=|doi=10.1007/s00531-005-0063-5}}</ref> * Federico L., Capponi G., Crispini L. & Bradshaw J.D. - 2007 - The Cambrian Ross Orogeny in Northern Victoria Land (Antarctica) and New Zealand: A Synthesis. U.S. Geological Survey and The National Academies; USGS OF-2007-1047, Short Research Paper 063, doi:10.3133/of2007-1047.srp063.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Federico|first=L.|last2=Capponi|first2=G.|last3=Crispini|first3=L.|date=2007|title=The Cambrian Ross Orogeny in Northern Victoria Land (Antarctica) and New Zealand: A Synthesis|url=https://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2007/1047/srp/srp063/index.html|journal=U.S. Geological Survey and The National Academies|language=en|volume=063|doi=10.3133/of2007-1047.srp063}}</ref> * CRISPINI L., DiVincenzo G. and Palmeri R. - 2007 - Petrology and 40Ar-39Ar dating of shear zones in the Lanterman Range (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica): implications for metamorphic and temporal evolution at the terrane boundaries - Mineralogy and Petrology, 89: 217–249 doi: 10.1007/s00710-006-0164-2.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Crispini|first=L.|last2=DiVincenzo|first2=G.|last3=Palmeri|first3=R.|date=2007|title=Petrology and 40Ar-39Ar dating of shear zones in the Lanterman Range (northern Victoria Land, Antarctica): implications for metamorphic and temporal evolution at the terrane boundaries|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00710-006-0164-2|journal=Mineralogy and Petrology|language=en|volume=89|pages=217–249|doi=10.1007/s00710-006-0164-2|bibcode=2007MinPe..89..217C}}</ref> * Federico L, CRISPINI L., Capponi G, Bradshaw J.D (2009). {{Infobox Airline |airline = MAT Airways |logo = |logo_size = |fleet_size = 1 |destinations = 11 |IATA = 6F |ICAO = MKD |callsign = MATAIRWAYS |parent = Kon Tiki Travel Serbia |company_slogan = |founded = March 2009 |ceased = 2011 |headquarters = [[Skopje]], [[Republic of Macedonia]] |key_people = |hubs = [[Skopje "Alexander the Great" Airport]] |secondary_hubs = [[Ohrid "St. Paul the Apostle" Airport]] |focus_cities = |frequent_flyer = |lounge = |alliance = |website = http://www.matairways.mk/ }} [[File:MAT Airways Boeing 737-529; Z3-AAM@ZRH;26.12.2010 591ch (5318942161).jpg|thumb|The Boeing 737-500 of MAT Airways]] '''MAT Airways''' was an airline based in [[Skopje]], [[Republic of Macedonia]]. Its main base was [[Skopje "Alexander the Great" Airport]]. ==History== The biggest Serbian tourist agency Kon Tiki Travel, Belgrade, and Metropolitan Investment Group, Belgrade, in accordance with Macedonian statutory regulations have established the new air transport company. The airline leased its first aircraft from [[Aviogenex]], however, this plane has been returned to its owner. [[Skywings International Airlines]], Macedonia’s largest charter airline, was left without an operating license and decided to merge with its rival MAT, with the aim of reducing costs and optimizing operations. As a result, MAT operated 2 aircraft. In May 2011 Skywings decided to split from MAT, only a month after they merged. On Monday, 4 July it was announced that MAT Airways has suspended its services. Their only aircraft is currently grounded and it's not announced when they will resume flights. The Macedonian Civil Aviation Agency says that it did not play a part in MAT’s service suspension and adds that the airline has a permit to operate flights from Skopje and Ohrid to Zurich, Düsseldorf, Berlin, Hamburg, Vienna and Copenhagen until June 15, 2012. On Friday, 15 July MAT Airways resumed their services. The airline voluntarily grounded its sole aircraft, a Boeing 737-500. According to MAT’s management it did so in order to review its position on the market in face of increased competition. However, other sources claim that the airline has been having financial problems. ==Destinations== According to the Skopje Airport and MAT Airways websites, MAT operated the following service (as of May 2011): The airlines is now closed down ===Europe=== *'''[[Belgium]] ** [[Brussels]] - [[Brussels Airport]] *'''[[Germany]]''' ** [[Berlin]] - [[Berlin Schönefeld Airport]] ** [[Düsseldorf]] - [[Düsseldorf Airport]] **[[Hamburg]] - [[Hamburg Airport]] **[[Stuttgart]] - [[Stuttgart Airport]] *'''[[Italy]]''' ** [[Rome]] - [[Leonardo da Vinci-Fiumicino Airport]] *'''[[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]''' **[[Ohrid]] - [[Ohrid "St. Paul the Apostle" Airport]] '''[Secondary Hub]''' **[[Skopje]] - [[Skopje "Alexander the Great" Airport]] '''[Hub]''' *'''[[Switzerland]]''' ** [[Zurich]] - [[Zurich Airport]] ==Fleet== The MAT Airways fleet included the following aircraft ({{as of|2011|7|7|lc=on}}):
{|class="toccolours" border="1" cellpadding="3" style="border-collapse:collapse" |+'''MAT Airways Fleet''' |- bgcolor=lightblue !Aircraft !Total !Orders !Passengers
(Business/Economy) !Operated |- |[[Boeing 737 Classic|Boeing 737-500]] |align="center"|1 |align="center"|0 |align="center"|12/108 |align="center"|1 |- |'''Total''' !1 !0 ! | |}
==External links== {{commons category|MAT Airways}} {{Portal|Macedonia|Aviation}} *{{Official website|http://www.matairways.mk/}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Airlines of Macedonia}} [[Category:Defunct airlines of the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Airlines established in 2010]] [[Category:Airlines disestablished in 2011]] {{europe-airline-stub}} {{RMacedonia-company-stub}}

'''Metropolitan Beacon System''' ('''MBS''') is a precise three dimensional location and timing technology designed to provide services to entire metropolitan areas where [[GPS]] or other satellite location signals are blocked or can’t be reliably received.<ref>{{cite web|title=Metropolitan Beacon System : GPS World|url=http://gpsworld.com/tag/metropolitan-beacon-system/|website=gpsworld.com}}</ref>
[[NextNav]] is one of the early adapters and developers of MBS.<ref>{{cite web|title=NextNav and Broadcom Partner for Indoor Accuracy|url=http://gpsworld.com/nextnav-and-broadcom-partner-for-indoor-accuracy/|website=GPS World|language=en-US|date=22 October 2013}}</ref>

revision.comment: /* Impact on jobs in western countries */
revision.text:
{{about|the business process|other uses|Offshore (disambiguation)}}
'''Offshoring''' is the relocation of a [[business process]] from one country to another—typically an operational process, such as manufacturing, or supporting processes, such as accounting. Typically this refers to a [[company]] business, although state governments may also employ offshoring.<ref>"The Offshoring of American Government", Cornell Law Review, Nov. 2008, available: http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1143044</ref> More recently, offshoring has been associated primarily with the [[outsourcing]] of technical and administrative services supporting domestic and global operations from outside the home country ("[[offshore outsourcing]]"), by means of internal (captive) or external (outsourcing) delivery models.<ref name="Papers.ssrn.com">{{cite journal|ssrn=1287369 |title=SSRN-A Dynamic Perspective on Next-Generation Offshoring: The Global Sourcing of Science and Engineering Talent |authors=Stephan Manning, Silvia Massini, Arie Lewin |journal=[[Academy of Management Perspectives]]|volume=22|issue=3|pages=35–54|publisher=[[Social Science Electronic Publishing]]|date=October 20, 2008 |accessdate=|doi=10.5465/amp.2008.34587994}}</ref>
The term is in use in several distinct but closely related ways. It is sometimes used broadly to include substitution of a service from any foreign source for a service formerly produced internally to the firm. In other cases, only imported services from subsidiaries or other closely related suppliers are included. A further complication is that intermediate goods, such as partially completed computers, are not consistently included in the scope of the term.<ref>See "Appendix II: Definitions of Offshoring" in General Accounting Office: "International Trade: Current Government Data Provide Limited Insight into Offshoring of Services", September 2004. Imported intermediate goods are included in offshoring in "Swenson, D: "International Outsourcing", in ''[[The New Palgrave Dictionary of Economics]]'', 2008.</ref>
Offshoring can be seen in the context of either production offshoring or services offshoring. After its accession to the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) in 2001, the [[People's Republic of China]] emerged as a prominent destination for production offshoring. Another focus area has been the [[software industry]] as part of global [[software development]] and developing [[global information system]]s. After technical progress in telecommunications improved the possibilities of [[trade in services]], [[India]] became one prominent destination for such offshoring, though many parts of the world are now emerging as offshore destinations.
The economic logic is to reduce costs, sometimes called [[labor arbitrage]], to improve corporate profitability. Jobs are added in the destination country providing the goods or services (generally a lower-cost labor country), but are subtracted in the higher-cost labor country.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Miszczynski|first=Milosz|date=2016-06-22|title=Labour arbitrage: the lifecycle of a global production node|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/JOE-04-2016-0009|journal=Journal of Organizational Ethnography|volume=5|issue=2|pages=106–122|doi=10.1108/JOE-04-2016-0009|issn=2046-6749}}</ref> The increased safety net costs of the unemployed may be absorbed by the government (taxpayers) in the high-cost country or by the company doing the offshoring. Europe experienced less offshoring than the United States due to policies that applied more costs to corporations and cultural barriers.<ref name="economist.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21569567-european-jobs-are-not-coming-back-because-few-them-went-first-place-staying-put|title=Staying put. European jobs are not coming back because few of them went in the first place|date=January 2013|work=[[The Economist]]|accessdate=8 April 2014}}</ref>
== Frequently used terms == Offshoring is defined as the movement of a business process done at a company in one country to the same or another company in another, different country. Almost always work is moved because of a lower cost of operations in the new location. More recently, offshoring drivers also include access to qualified personnel abroad, in particular in technical professions, and increasing speed to market.<ref name="Papers.ssrn.com"/> Offshoring is sometimes contrasted with [[outsourcing]] or [[offshore outsourcing]]. Outsourcing is the movement of internal business processes to an external organizational unit. Outsourcing refers to the process by which an organization gives part of its work to another firm / organization and makes it responsible for most of the applications as well as the design of the enterprise business process. This process is done under restrictions and strategies in order to establish consistency with the offshore outsourcing organizations. Many companies nowadays outsource various professional areas in the company such as e-mail services, payroll and [[call center]]. These jobs are being handled by other organizations that specialize in each sector allowing the offshoring company to focus more on other business concerns. However, subcontracting in the same country would be outsourcing, but not offshoring. A company moving an internal business unit from one country to another would be offshoring or [[physical restructuring]], but not outsourcing. A company subcontracting a business unit to a different company in another country would be both outsourcing and offshoring.
Related terms include [[nearshoring]], which implies relocation of business processes to (typically) lower cost foreign locations, but in close geographical proximity (e.g., shifting [[United States]]-based business processes to [[Canada]]/[[Latin America]]); inshoring, which means picking services within a country; and [[bestshoring]] or rightshoring, picking the "best shore" based on various criteria. [[Business process outsourcing]] (BPO) refers to outsourcing arrangements when entire business functions (such as [[Finance]] & [[Accounting]], Customer Service, etc.) are outsourced. More specific terms can be found in the field of software development - for example [[Global Information System]] as a class of systems being developed for / by globally distributed teams.
A further term sometimes associated with offshoring is [[bodyshopping]] which is the practice of using offshored resources and personnel to do small disaggregated tasks within a business environment, without any broader intention to offshore an entire business function.
=== Production offshoring === Production offshoring, also known as [[physical restructuring]], of established products involves relocation of physical manufacturing processes to a lower-cost destination. Examples of production offshoring include the manufacture of electronic components in [[Costa Rica]], production of apparel, toys, and consumer goods in China, [[Vietnam]] etc.
Product design, research and the development process that leads to new products, are relatively difficult to offshore. This is because research and development, in order to improve products and create new reference designs, require a skill set that is harder to obtain in regions with cheap labor. For this reason, in many cases only the manufacturing will be offshored by a company wishing to reduce costs.
However, there is a relationship between offshoring and patent-system strength. This is because companies under a strong patent system are not afraid to move work offshore because their work will remain their property. Conversely, companies in countries with weak patent systems have an increased fear of intellectual property theft from foreign vendors or workers, and, therefore, have less offshoring.
A major incentive for [[physical restructuring]] arrived when the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) made it easier for manufacturers to shift production facilities from the US to [[Mexico]]. This trend later shifted to China, which offered cheap prices through very low wage rates, few [[workers' rights]] laws, a [[fixed currency]] pegged to the US dollar, (currently fixed to a basket of economies) cheap loans, cheap land, and factories for new companies, few environmental regulations, and huge [[economies of scale]] based on cities with populations over a million workers dedicated to producing a single kind of product. However, many companies are reluctant to move high value-added production of leading-edge products to China because of lax enforcement of intellectual property laws.<ref>Fishman, T: "China, Inc." Scribner, 2006.</ref> NAFTA has increased the velocity at which [[physical restructuring]] is occurring.
=== IT-enabled services offshoring === The growth of IT-enabled services offshoring is linked to the availability of large amounts of reliable and affordable communication infrastructure following the telecommunication and Internet expansion of the late 1990s. This was seen all the way up to the year 2000. Coupled with the digitization of many services, it was possible to shift the actual production location of services to low-cost countries in a manner theoretically transparent to end-users. Services include administrative services, such as finance and accounting, HR, and legal; call centers; marketing and sales services; IT infrastructure; application development; and knowledge services, including engineering support, product design, research and development, and analytics.
India first benefited from the offshoring trend, as it has a large pool of [[English language|English]] speaking people and technically proficient manpower.<ref>[http://repositories.cdlib.org/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1027&context=cgirs Working Through Outsourcing: Software Practice, Industry Organization and Industry Evolution in India] Kyle Eischen. eScholarship Repository, 2006. Retrieved 25 November 2006.</ref> India's offshoring industry took root in low-end IT functions in the early 1990s and has since moved to back-office processes such as call centers and transaction processing. This spawned the [[neologism]] ''Bangalored'', used to indicate a [[layoff]], often systemic, and usually resulting from corporate [[outsourcing]] to lower wage economies – derived from [[Bangalore]] in [[India]], where some of the first outsource centers were located.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldwidewords.org/turnsofphrase/tp-ban1.htm|title=World Wide Words: Bangalored|work=World Wide Words|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref>
Currently, India's low-cost labor has made it an offshoring destination for global firms like [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]], [[IBM]], [[Accenture]], [[Intel]], [[AMD]], [[Microsoft]], [[Oracle Corporation]], [[Cisco]] and [[SAP AG|SAP]].
Because of inflation, high domestic interest rates, robust economic growth and increased IT offshoring, the Indian IT sector has witnessed 10 - 15% wage growth in the 21st century. Consequently, Indian's operations and firms are concerned that they are becoming too expensive in comparison with competition from the other offshoring destinations. To maintain high growth rates, attempts have been made to grow up the value chain and diversify to other high-end work in addition to software and hardware engineering. These jobs include research and development, equity analysis, tax-return processing, radiological analysis, [[medical transcription]], and more.
The choice of offshoring destination is often made according to cultural concerns. Japanese companies are starting to outsource to China, where large numbers of Japanese speakers can be found—particularly in the city of [[Dalian]], which was Japanese-occupied Chinese territory for decades (this is discussed in the book ''[[The World is Flat]]''). German companies tend to outsource to [[Eastern Europe]]an countries, such as [[Poland]] and [[Romania]], where proficiency in German is common.<ref name="http">{{cite journal |first=Stephan |last=Manning |first2=Jörg |last2=Sydow |first3=Arnold |last3=Windeler |title=Securing Access to Lower-cost Talent Globally: The Dynamics of Active Embedding and Field Structuration |journal=Regional Studies |volume=46 |year=2012 |issue=9 |pages=1201–1218 |doi=10.1080/00343404.2011.571243 }}</ref> French companies outsource to North Africa for similar reasons. For Australian IT companies, [[Indonesia]] is one of the major choice of offshoring destination. Near-shore location, common time zone and adequate IT work force are the reasons for offshoring IT services to Indonesia.
Other offshoring destinations include [[Mexico]], [[Colombia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bnamericas.com/news/technology/colombia-moves-towards-top-of-outsourcing-a-list-says-nearshore-americas|title=Colombia Moves Towards Top of Outsourcing A-List|work=BnAmericas|accessdate=3 June 2013}}</ref> [[Central America|Central]] and [[South America]], the [[Philippines]], [[South Africa]] and [[Eastern Europe]]an countries.
The [[Central America Free Trade Agreement]] (CAFTA) made [[nearshoring]] more attractive between the Central American countries of [[Costa Rica]], [[El Salvador]], [[Guatemala]], [[Honduras]], [[Nicaragua]], and the [[Dominican Republic]] and the US.
=== Innovation offshoring === Once companies are comfortable with services offerings and started realizing the cost savings, many high-tech product companies, including some in [[Silicon Valley]], started offshoring innovation work to countries like [[Colombia]], [[Belarus]], South Africa, India, China, Mexico, Russia and Ukraine. Accessing the talent pools in these countries has the potential to cut costs or even shorten product lifecycles. Developing countries like India are also involved in this practice.
When offshoring knowledge work, firms heavily rely on the availability of technical personnel at offshore locations. One of the challenges in offshoring engineering innovation is a reduction in quality.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moe|first=Nils Brede|last2=Šmite|first2=Darja|last3=Hanssen|first3=Geir Kjetil|last4=Barney|first4=Hamish|date=2013-08-29|title=From offshore outsourcing to insourcing and partnerships: four failed outsourcing attempts|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10664-013-9272-x|journal=Empirical Software Engineering|language=en|volume=19|issue=5|pages=1225–1258|doi=10.1007/s10664-013-9272-x|issn=1382-3256}}</ref> In order to secure access to talent and possibly improve long-term quality, Western firms often establish collaborative relationships with technical universities abroad and thereby customize university programs to serve their particular needs. Examples include universities in Shanghai, such as [[Tong-Ji University]], where German firms and scholars co-sponsor labs, courses, and provide internships. Similar examples of collaborative arrangements can be found in Eastern Europe, e.g. Romania.<ref name="http"/> Additionally, EU companies looking for IT innovation often setup collaboration with universities in countries such as Belarus and Ukraine, which have a high percentage of ICT graduates and overall a very skilled IT labor.<ref>Opportunities for EU ICT Actors. Oct 2009. http://www.eeca-ict.eu/uploads/dmdocuments/Opportunities_Report_for_EU_ICT_actors_in_UKRAINE.pdf {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140327141043/http://www.eeca-ict.eu/uploads/dmdocuments/Opportunities_Report_for_EU_ICT_actors_in_UKRAINE.pdf |date=2014-03-27 }}</ref> Other ways to mitigate quality challenges include dual exposure between Western and offshore development teams, significant interview period, equity options for key personnel, and PR presence<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/27/build-an-offshore-development-team-that-wont-suck/|title=Build An Offshore Development Team That Won’t Suck|last=Mikado|first=Mikita|date=2015-11-27|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-09-08|language=en-US}}</ref>.
===Re-shoring=== {{see also|Insourcing}} "Re-shoring", also known as "backshoring"<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.workforce.com/section/09/feature/25/27/70/ |title=Workforce Management Online, Dec 2007 |access-date=2010-04-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217231946/http://www.workforce.com/section/09/feature/25/27/70 |archive-date=2013-12-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> or "inshoring"<ref>{{cite web |title=Inshoring |publisher=Mike Karlesky |date=17 May 2005 |url=http://www.wordspy.com/words/inshoring.asp |accessdate=31 July 2008}}</ref> is offshoring that has been brought back onshore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zacks.com/stock/news/91918/reshoring-bringing-back-jobs-to-usa|title=Reshoring Bringing Back Jobs to USA|author=Zacks Investment Research|date=29 April 2015|work=Zacks Investment Research|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref>
John Urry (distinguished professor of sociology at [[Lancaster University]]) argues that the concealment of income, the avoidance of taxation and eluding legislation relating to work, finance, pleasure, waste, energy and security may be becoming a serious concern for democratic governments and ordinary citizens who may be adversely affected by unregulated, offshore activities. Further, the rising costs of transportation could lead to production nearer the point of consumption becoming more economically viable, particularly as new technologies such as [[3D printing|additive manufacturing]] mature<ref>{{cite book |title=Offshoring|author=John Urry|date=14 April 2014|isbn= 978-0745664866|publisher=polity UK}}</ref>
== Transfer of intellectual property == Offshoring is often enabled by the transfer of valuable information to the offshore site. Such information and training enables the remote workers to produce results of comparable value previously produced by internal employees. When such transfer includes protected materials, as confidential documents and trade secrets, protected by [[non-disclosure agreement]]s, then [[intellectual property]] has been transferred or exported. The documentation and valuation of such exports is quite difficult, but should be considered since it comprises items that may be regulated or taxable.
== Debate == Offshoring has been a controversial issue spurring heated debates among economists, some of which overlap those related to the topic of [[free trade]]. It is seen as benefiting both the origin and destination country through [[free trade]], providing jobs to the destination country and lower cost of goods and services to the origin country. This makes both sides see increased [[gross domestic product]] (GDP). And the total number of jobs increases in both countries since those workers in the origin country that lost their job can move to higher-value jobs in which their country has a [[comparative advantage]].
On the other hand, job losses and wage erosion in developed countries have sparked opposition to offshoring. Experts argue that the quality of any new jobs in developed countries are less than the jobs lost and offer lower pay. Economists against offshoring charge that currency manipulation by governments and their central banks causes the difference in labor cost creating an illusion of comparative advantage. Further, they point out that even more educated highly trained workers with higher-value jobs such as software engineers, accountants, radiologists, and journalists in the developed world have been displaced by highly educated and cheaper workers from India and China. On May 1, 2002, Economist and former Ambassador [[Ernest H. Preeg]] testified before the Senate committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs that China, for instance, pegs its currency to the dollar at a sub-par value in violation of Article IV of the [[International Monetary Fund]] Articles of Agreement which state that no nation shall manipulate its currency to gain a market advantage.<ref>Ernest H. Preeg (May 1, 2002). [http://www.mapi.net/html/testimony2.html Testimony on Chinese Currency Manipulation] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427064913/http://www.mapi.net/html/testimony2.html |date=2006-04-27 }} Manufacturers Alliance</ref>
===Impact on jobs in western countries=== ''The Economist'' reported in January 2013 that: "High levels of unemployment in Western countries after the 2007-2008 financial crisis have made the public in many countries so hostile towards offshoring that many companies are now reluctant to engage in it."<ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21569572-after-decades-sending-work-across-world-companies-are-rethinking-their-offshoring The Economist-Here, there and everywhere-January 2013]</ref> Economist [[Paul Krugman]] wrote in 2007 that while free trade among high-wage countries is viewed as win-win, free trade with low-wage countries is win-lose for many employees who find their jobs offshored or with stagnating wages.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/28/opinion/28krugman.html NYT-Paul Krugman-Trouble with Trade-December 2007]</ref> Two estimates of the impact of offshoring on U.S. jobs were between 150,000 and 300,000 per year from 2004-2015. This represents 10-15% of U.S. job creation.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21569568-offshored-jobs-return-rich-countries-must-prove-they-have-what-it-takes-shape The Economist-What to Do Now: Shape Up-January 2013]</ref>
The increased safety net costs of the unemployed may be absorbed by the government (taxpayers) in the high-cost country or by the company doing the offshoring. Europe experienced less offshoring than the U.S. due to policies that applied more costs to corporations and cultural barriers.<ref name="economist.com"/>
Research has found that offshoring has mixed effects on wages and employment,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Amiti|first=Mary|last2=Wei|first2=Shang-Jin|last3=Haskel|first3=Jonathan|last4=Auriol|first4=Emmanuelle|date=2005|title=Fear of Service Outsourcing: Is It Justified? |journal=Economic Policy|volume=20|issue=42|pages=307–347|doi=10.2307/3601072}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Groshen|first=Erica|last2=Hobijn|first2=Bart|last3=McConnell|first3=Margaret M.|date=2005|title=U.S. jobs gained and lost through trade: a net measure|url=http://econpapers.repec.org/article/fipfednci/y_3a2005_3ai_3aaug_3an_3av.11no.8.htm|journal=Current Issues in Economics and Finance|volume=11|issue=Aug}}</ref> with some studies showing insignificant effects,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Liu|first=Runjuan|last2=Trefler|first2=Daniel|date=June 2008|title=Much Ado About Nothing: American Jobs and the Rise of Service Outsourcing to China and India|work=NBER Working Paper No. 14061 |doi=10.3386/w14061 }}</ref> some showing negative effects,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ebenstein|first=Avraham|last2=Harrison|first2=Ann|last3=McMillan|first3=Margaret|last4=Phillips|first4=Shannon|date=2013-05-15|title=Estimating the Impact of Trade and Offshoring on American Workers using the Current Population Surveys |journal=The Review of Economics and Statistics|volume=96|issue=4|pages=581–595|doi=10.1162/rest_a_00400|issn=0034-6535}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pierce|first=Justin R.|last2=Schott|first2=Peter K.|date=July 2016|title=The Surprisingly Swift Decline of US Manufacturing Employment |journal=American Economic Review|volume=106|issue=7|pages=1632–1662|doi=10.1257/aer.20131578|issn=0002-8282}}</ref> whereas other studies have found that offshoring actually increases low-skilled employment and wages in the offshoring country.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Feenstra|first=Robert C.|last2=Hanson|first2=Gordon H.|date=1996|title=Globalization, Outsourcing, and Wage Inequality |journal=The American Economic Review|volume=86|issue=2|pages=240–245|doi=10.2307/2118130}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ottaviano|first=Gianmarco I. P|last2=Peri|first2=Giovanni|last3=Wright|first3=Greg C|date=2013|title=Immigration, Offshoring, and American Jobs |journal=American Economic Review|volume=103|issue=5|pages=1925–1959|doi=10.1257/aer.103.5.1925|issn=0002-8282|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grossman|first=Gene M.|last2=Rossi-Hansberg|first2=Esteban|date=2008|title=Trading Tasks: A Simple Theory of Offshoring |journal=American Economic Review|volume=98|issue=5|pages=1978–1997|doi=10.1257/aer.98.5.1978}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wright|first=Greg C.|date=2014-02-01|title=Revisiting the employment impact of offshoring |journal=European Economic Review|volume=66|pages=63–83|doi=10.1016/j.euroecorev.2013.11.008}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Feenstra|first=Robert C.|last2=Hanson|first2=Gordon H.|date=1999-08-01|title=The Impact of Outsourcing and High-Technology Capital on Wages: Estimates For the United States, 1979–1990 |journal=The Quarterly Journal of Economics|volume=114|issue=3|pages=907–940|doi=10.1162/003355399556179|issn=0033-5533}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kovak|first=Brian K.|last2=Oldenski|first2=Lindsay|last3=Sly|first3=Nicholas|date=October 2017|title=The Labor Market Effects of Offshoring by U.S. Multinational Firms: Evidence from Changes in Global Tax Policies|work=NBER Working Paper No. 23947 |doi=10.3386/w23947 }}</ref> A 2017 study found that offshoring benefits "offshoring can generate wage and employment gains for both high- and low-skilled workers through a “technology channel” wherein it induces skill-complementary capital deepening and greater innovation in U.S. industries." The study also found that "offshoring increases real wages for both high- and low-skilled workers, but more so for the former, increasing inequality."
The [[World Bank]]'s 2019 [[World Development Report]] on the future of work <ref>[http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/816281518818814423/pdf/2019-WDR-Report.pdf World Bank World Development Report 2019: The Changing Nature of Work.]</ref> highlights how offshoring can shape the demand for skills in receiving countries and explores how increasing automation can lead to [[reshoring]] of production in some cases.
===Legal implications in Japan=== Japanese companies use offshoring to exploit foreign laborers, particularly Chinese and Vietnamese, in violation of the Employment Security Act and Labor Standard Act guidelines set by the Japanese [[Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare]]. Article 44 of the Employment Security Act implicitly bans unauthorized companies supplying domestic/foreign workers, regardless of their operating locations. The laws apply if at least one party among suppliers, clients and workers reside in Japan, and if the workers are part of the integral part of the chain of command of the client company or the supplier:
{{Cquote|No person shall carry out a labor supply business or have workers supplied by a person who carries out a labor supply business work under his/her own directions or orders, except in cases provided for in the following Article.|Employment Security Act}}
{{Cquote|Unless permitted by act, no person shall obtain profit by intervening, as a business, in the employment of other|Labor Standards Act<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japaneselawtranslation.go.jp/law/detail/?yo=%E5%8A%B4%E5%83%8D%E5%9F%BA%E6%BA%96%E6%B3%95&ft=2&re=01&ky=|title=日本法令外国語訳データベースシステム - [法令本文表示] - 労働基準法|publisher=|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref>}}
The Employment Security Act sets punishment guidelines as follows:
{{Cquote|A person who falls under any of the following items shall be punished by imprisonment with work for not more than one year or a fine of not more than one million yen|Employment Security Act states, Article 64}}
Victims can lodge a criminal complaint against the CEO's of the suppliers and clients to the Labor Standards Inspection Office (in the case of the Labor Standards Act) or Public Prosecutor's Office in the company's location. Due to the risk of CEO's arrest, Japanese companies tend to privately settle with plaintiffs, offering between 20 and 100 million JPY (approximately 200,000 - 1 million USD) in damages.
===Competitive concerns=== In 2015, IT employment in the United States has recently reached pre-2001 levels<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=185303797|title=IT Employment Reaches Record High In U.S.|work=InformationWeek|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.informationweek.com/blog/main/archives/2006/08/us_tech_workers.html|title=Business Technology News and Commentary - InformationWeek|work=InformationWeek|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref> and has been rising since. The number of jobs lost to offshoring is less than 1 percent of the total US labor market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heritage.org/Research/Economy/bg1757.cfm|title=Myths and Realities: The False Crisis of Outsourcing|work=The Heritage Foundation|accessdate=29 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100303032902/http://www.heritage.org/Research/Economy/bg1757.cfm|archive-date=3 March 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to a study by the Heritage foundation, outsourcing represents a very small proportion of jobs lost in the US. The total number of jobs lost to offshoring, both manufacturing and technical represent only 4 percent of the total jobs lost in the US. Major reasons for cutting jobs are from contract completion and downsizing.<ref name="newsweek.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/34690 |title=Samuelson: Debunking the Great Offshoring Myth |publisher=Newsweek.com |date=2007-08-21 |accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> Some economists and commentators claim that the offshoring phenomenon is way overblown.<ref name="newsweek.com"/>
=== Public opinion === U.S. opinion polls indicate that between 76-95% of Americans surveyed agreed that "outsourcing of production and manufacturing work to foreign countries is a reason the U.S. economy is struggling and more people aren't being hired."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703466104575529753735783116|title=Americans Sour on Trade|author=Sara Murray And Douglas Belkin|date=2 October 2010|work=WSJ|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="gallup.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/146915/americans-top-job-creation-idea-stop-sending-work-overseas.aspx|title=Americans’ Top Job–Creation Idea: Stop Sending Work Overseas|author=Gallup, Inc.|publisher=|accessdate=29 April 2015}}</ref>
== Effects of factor of production mobility == According to [[classical economics]], the three [[factors of production]] are [[land (economics)|land]], [[labor (economics)|labor]], and [[capital (economics)|capital]]. Offshoring relies heavily on the mobility of two of these factors. That is, how offshoring affects economies depends on how easily capital and labor can be repurposed. Land, as a factor of production, is generally seen to have little or no mobility potential.
The effects of [[capital mobility]] on offshoring have been widely discussed. In [[microeconomics]], a corporation must be able to spend [[working capital]] to afford the initial costs of offshoring. If the state heavily regulates how a corporation can spend its working capital, it will not be able to offshore its operations. For the same reason the [[macroeconomics|macroeconomy]] must be free for offshoring to succeed. Generally, those who favor offshoring support capital mobility, and those who oppose offshoring call for greater [[regulation]].
Labor mobility also plays a major role, and it is hotly debated. When computers and the Internet made work electronically portable, the forces of free market resulted in a global mobility of work in the services industry. Most theories that argue offshoring eventually benefits domestic workers assume that those workers will be able to obtain new jobs, even if they have to obtain employment by downpricing themselves back into the labor market (by accepting lower salaries) or by retraining themselves in a new field. Foreign workers benefit from new jobs and higher wages when the work moves to them.
Offshoring faces criticism from labor scholars who argue that [[global labor arbitrage]] leads to unethical practices, connected to exploitation of workers, eroding work conditions and decreasing job security.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Miszczynski|first=M.|date=2016-02-18|title=Global Production in a Romanian Village: Middle-Income Economy, Industrial Dislocation and the Reserve Army of Labor|url=http://crs.sagepub.com/cgi/doi/10.1177/0896920515623076|journal=Critical Sociology|doi=10.1177/0896920515623076}}</ref>
== History == In the developed world, moving manufacturing jobs out of the country dates to at least the 1960s<ref>General Accounting Office: [http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d06423.pdf "Offshoring: U.S. Semiconductor and Software Industries Increasingly Produce in China and India"], September 2006.</ref> while moving knowledge service jobs offshore dates to the 1970s<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.jom.2007.02.012|title=History of offshoring knowledge services|journal=Journal of Operations Management|volume=26|issue=2|pages=141|year=2008|last1=Metters|first1=Richard|last2=Verma|first2=Rohit}}</ref> and has continued since then. It was characterized primarily by the transferring of factories from the developed to the developing world. This offshoring and closing of factories has caused a structural change in the developed world from an industrial to a post-industrial service society.
During the 20th century, the decreasing costs of transportation and communication crossed with great disparities on pay rates made increased offshoring from wealthier countries to less wealthy countries financially feasible for many companies. Further, the growth of the [[Internet]], particularly fiber-optic intercontinental long haul capacity, and the [[World Wide Web]] reduced "transportation" costs for many kinds of information work to near zero.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite book |first=Sara |last=Baase |title=A Gift of Fire: Social, Legal, and Ethical Issues for Computing and The Internet |edition=Third |location=Harlow |publisher=Prentice Hall |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-13-600848-4 }}</ref>
With the development of the Internet, many new categories of work such as call centres, computer programming, reading medical data such as X-rays and [[magnetic resonance imaging]], medical transcription, income tax preparation, and title searching are being offshored.
Before the 1990s, Ireland was one of the poorest countries in the EU. Because of Ireland's relatively low corporate tax rates, US companies began offshoring of software, electronic, and pharmaceutical intellectual property to Ireland for export. This helped create a high-tech "boom" and which led to Ireland becoming one of the richest EU countries.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
In 1994 the [[North American Free Trade Agreement]] (NAFTA) went into effect. As concerns are widespread about uneven bargaining powers, and risks and benefits, negotiations are often difficult, such that the plan to create free trade areas (such as [[Free Trade Area of the Americas]]) has not yet been successful. In 2005, offshoring of skilled work, also referred to as knowledge work, dramatically increased from the US, which fed the growing worries about threats of job loss.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} *[[Anti-Globalism]] *[[Call center security]] *''[[Decline and Fall of the American Programmer]]'' *[[Domestic sourcing]] *[[Follow-the-sun]] *[[Global sourcing]] *[[Globality]] *[[Globally Integrated Enterprise]] *[[Homeshoring]] *[[Inshoring]] *[[Job migration]] *[[Low-cost country sourcing]] *[[Offshore company]] *[[Offshore outsourcing]] *[[Offshoring Research Network]] *[[Outsourcing]] *[[Personal offshoring]] *[[Programmers Guild]] *[[Restructuring]] *[[Runaway production]] *[[Tax haven]] {{div col end}} '''By sector:''' *[[Business process outsourcing]] *[[Information technology consulting]] *[[Legal outsourcing]] *[[Offshore software R&D]] *[[Offshore custom software development]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== Further reading == * [[Alan S. Blinder]], "[https://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/2006-03-01/offshoring-next-industrial-revolution Offshoring: The Next Industrial Revolution?]" in ''Foreign Affairs'', Vol. 85, No. 2 (March/April 2006), pp. 113–128. * Thomas L. Friedman, ''[[The World is Flat: A Brief History of the Twenty-first Century]]'' (2005). * Catherine L. Mann & Jacob Funk Kirkegaard, ''Accelerating the Globalization of America: The Role for Information Technology'', Institute for International Economics, Washington D.C., [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]] (June 2006). * Stephan Manning, Silvia Massini & Arie Y. Lewin, A Dynamic Perspective on Next-Generation Offshoring: The Global Sourcing of Science and Engineering Talent, ''Academy of Management Perspectives'', Vol. 22, No. 3 (October 2008), pp. 35–54. {{JSTOR|27747462}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Ciudad Real |latin = Dioecesis Civitatis Regalensis |local = Diócesis de Ciudad Real | image = Ciudad Real - Catedral de Nuestra Señora del Prado 1.jpg | image_size = 230px | image_alt = | caption = [[Ciudad Real Cathedral]] |country = {{flag|Spain}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Toledo|Toledo]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Toledo|Toledo]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |established = 18 November 1875 (As Territorial Prelature of Ciudad Real)
4 February 1980 (As Diocese of Ciudad Real) |denomination = [[Roman Catholic]] |cathedral = [[Ciudad Real Cathedral|Cathedral Basilica of Our Lady of the Meadows in Ciudad Real]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 19,813 |population = 500,060 |population_as_of = 2006 |catholics = 493,060 |catholics_percent= 98.6 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Antonio Angel Algora Hernando]] |metro_archbishop = [[Braulio Rodríguez Plaza]] |emeritus_bishops = Rafael Torija de la Fuente Bishop Emeritus (1980-2003) |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |map = Diócesis de Ciudad Real.svg |website = [http://www.diocesisciudadreal.es/ Website of the Diocese] }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Ciudad Real''' ({{lang-la|Civitatis Regalen(sis)}}) is a [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Ciudad Real]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Toledo|Toledo]] in Spain. ==History== * 18 November 1875: Established as Territorial Prelature of Ciudad Real * 4 February 1980: Promoted as Diocese of Ciudad Real ==Leadership== * Prelates of Ciudad Real (Roman rite) **Victoriano Guisasola y Rodríguez (28 May 1877 – 27 Mar 1882 ) **Antonio María Cascajares y Azara (27 Mar 1882 – 27 Mar 1884 ) **José María Rancés y Villanueva † (10 Jun 1886 – 28 Nov 1898) **Casimiro Piñera y Naredo † (28 Nov 1898 – 28 Aug 1904 Died) **Remigio Gandásegui y Gorrochátegui (27 Mar 1905 – 28 May 1914 ) **Francisco Javier de Irastorza Loinaz (11 Jul 1914 – 27 Jun 1922 ) **Bl. Narciso de Esténaga y Echevarría (14 Dec 1922 – 22 Aug 1936 ) **Emeterio Echeverria Barrena (29 Dec 1942 – 25 Dec 1954 Died) **Juan Hervás y Benet (14 Mar 1955 – 30 Sep 1976 ) * [[Bishop]]s of Ciudad Real (Roman rite) **Rafael Torija de la Fuente (30 Sep 1976 – 20 Mar 2003 ) **Antonio Angel Algora Hernando (20 Mar 2003 – ) ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Spain]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Wikisource1913CatholicEnc|Ciudad Real}} ==External links== * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/ciud7.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dcire.html Catholic Hierarchy] [[Wikipedia:Verifiability#Reliable sources|{{sup|{{small|[''self-published'']}}}}]] * [http://www.iglesiaendaimiel.com/ Diocese website] {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain}} {{coord|38.9867|N|3.9311|W|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:ES|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ciudad Real}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Spain]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1875]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 19th century]] {{Spain-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

page.title: Society of Malawi, Historical and Scientific

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = |bibanabibanabibanabibanabibana | merger = | type = | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for non-profit org) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = To promote interest in literary, historical and scientific matters that relate to Malawi, as well as to discover and record facts and information about Malawi which might otherwise be lost. | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | region = | services = | products = Malawi Society bi-annual journal | methods = | fields = | membership = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = Patron: President of Malawi, [[Peter Mutharika]] | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | revenue = | disbursements = | expenses = | endowment = | staff = | volunteers = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://www.societyofmalawi.org}} | remarks = | formerly = }} The '''Society of Malawi, Historical and Scientific''' is a not-for-profit organisation established in 1947, as the Nyasaland Society. It changed its name after [[Malawi]] gained independence in 1964. The Society aims to promote interest in literary, historical and scientific matters, discover and record facts and information about Malawi which might otherwise be lost. It also acquires books relating to Malawi.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.societyofmalawi.org|title = Society of Malawi, Historical and Scientific - Home|date = |accessdate = 17 December 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The patron of the library is always the president of Malawi, the current one being [[Arthur Peter Mutharika]]
==Programmes== The Society publishes a journal twice yearly. The journal is edited by [[David Stuart-Mogg]] and [[Professor Colin Baker]].  Stuart-Mogg is a keen amateur historian who also published a best selling Guide to Malawi and numerous papers and articles mainly on Malawi’s rich cultural heritage, maintaining a special interest in the [[John Chilembwe]] phenomenon<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.davidstuartmogg.com/?page_id=213|title = David Stuart-Mogg|date = |accessdate = 17 December 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> while Baker has published extensively on Malawi.<ref>{{Cite web|jstor = 29779046|title = Colin Baker at 70: an appreciation|date = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
It also has a reference library and archives located at the historic [[Mandala House]], Malawi's oldest standing building in  [[Blantyre]] built in 1882. The library is open to both the public and Society members. [[File:Mandala Manager's House, Blantyre.jpg|alt= Mandala Manager's House, Malawi's oldest building|right|thumb|Mandala Manager's House, Malawi's oldest building]]
== The Transport Museum at the Heritage Centre, Blantyre == The Society also runs a Transport Museum, located in the Heritage Centre in [[Limbe, Blantyre, Malawi|Limbe]] on land granted by the Malawi Railways with the proviso that the history of transport in Malawi be preserved with emphasis on the Railways role in opening up Nyasaland, a land-locked country, to the sea.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.societyofmalawi.org/tptmuseum.php|title = Society of Malawi - Transport Museum|date = |accessdate = 17 December 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Exhibits at the museum cover the period from 1867 to 1996 and include fully captioned photographs, artefacts, and other items of interest.[[File:Locomotive Number 9 at Limbe, May 1924.jpg|thumb|Locomotive Number 9 at Limbe, May 1924]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:History of Malawi]] [[Category:Organisations based in Malawi]] [[Category:Blantyre]]
{{Africa-org-stub}} {{Malawi-stub}}

revision.comment: /* Cycle World Record Progression */ fixing table
revision.text:
[[World record]]s in [[sport stacking]] are maintained by the [[World Sport Stacking Association]] (WSSA). Sport stacking world records can be set at sanctioned WSSA events. The WSSA reviews video of potential world record attempts before certifying a time as a new world record.{{cite web|url=http://www.thewssa.com/records/how_to_set_a_record/|title=How to Set A Record|website=World Sport Stacking Association (The WSSA)|access-date=2015-11-09}} ==World Records== ===Male=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! [[File:EFF photograph of NSA's Utah Data Center.jpg|thumb|400px|NSA's Utah Data Center]]
{{Global surveillance}} The '''Utah Data Center''' (UDC), also known as the '''Intelligence Community Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative Data Center''',<ref name="facs1">{{cite news | title = NSA Utah Data Center | url = http://www.facilitiesmagazine.com/utah/buildings/nsa-utah-data-center | newspaper = Facilities Magazine | date = 14 September 2011 | accessdate = 24 April 2013 }}</ref> is a [[Computer data storage|data storage]] facility for the [[United States Intelligence Community]] that is designed to store data estimated to be on the order of [[exabytes]] or larger.<ref name="forbes1">{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kashmirhill/2013/07/24/blueprints-of-nsa-data-center-in-utah-suggest-its-storage-capacity-is-less-impressive-than-thought/|title=Blueprints Of NSA's Ridiculously Expensive Data Center In Utah Suggest It Holds Less Info Than Thought|date=July 24, 2013|author=Kashmir Hill|accessdate=2013-07-29|work=Forbes}}</ref> Its purpose is to support the [[Comprehensive National Cybersecurity Initiative]] (CNCI), though its precise mission is classified.<ref name="deseret1">{{cite news | title = Utah's $1.5 billion cyber-security center under way | first = Steve | last = Fidel | url = http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705363940/Utahs-15-billion-cyber-security-center-under-way.html | newspaper = Deseret News | date = 6 January 2011 | accessdate = 29 March 2013 }}</ref> The [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) leads operations at the facility as the executive agent for the [[Director of National Intelligence]].<ref name="reuters1">{{cite news | title = U.S. agency denies data center to monitor citizens' emails | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/04/16/us-usa-security-nsa-idUSBRE93E11O20130416 | newspaper = [[Reuters]] | date = 15 April 2013 | accessdate = 16 April 2013 | first=Andrea | last=Shalal-Esa }}</ref> It is located at [[Camp Williams]] near [[Bluffdale, Utah]], between [[Utah Lake]] and [[Great Salt Lake]] and was completed in May 2014 at a cost of $1.5 billion.<ref>{{cite web |author=Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology and Logistics |date=September 17, 2014 |title=MilCon Status Report - August, 2014 - Under Secretary of Defense for AT&L |url=http://www.acq.osd.mil/ie/fim/library/milcon/MILCON_EOM-AUG_Report_2014-09-17.xlsx |access-date=April 16, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210071515/http://www.acq.osd.mil/ie/fim/library/milcon/MILCON_EOM-AUG_Report_2014-09-17.xlsx |archive-date=December 10, 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Purpose== The data center is alleged to be able to process "all forms of communication, including the complete contents of private emails, cell phone calls, and Internet searches, as well as all types of personal data trails — parking receipts, travel itineraries, bookstore purchases, and other digital 'pocket litter'."<ref name="bamford1">{{cite news|title=The NSA Is Building the Country's Biggest Spy Center (Watch What You Say)|first=James|last=Bamford|authorlink=James Bamford|url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2012/03/ff_nsadatacenter/all/1|newspaper=Wired|date=15 March 2012|access-date=5 April 2012}}</ref> In response to claims that the data center would be used to illegally monitor email of U.S. citizens, in April 2013 an NSA spokesperson said, "Many unfounded allegations have been made about the planned activities of the Utah Data Center, ... one of the biggest misconceptions about NSA is that we are unlawfully listening in on, or reading emails of, U.S. citizens. This is simply not the case."<ref name="reuters1" /> This statement was made two months prior to the document leak that revealed the existence of the PRISM program (below). Some members of the public question the credibility of official statements like Bamford's, above, in light of the revelations made in the following two paragraphs herein, and in light of the revelations made in the following two months after his statement was made.
[[File:Utah Data Center Panorama.jpg|thumb|left|450px|Utah Data Center, [[Bluffdale, Utah|Bluffdale]], Utah ([[United States]])]] In April 2009, officials at the [[United States Department of Justice]] acknowledged that the NSA had engaged in large-scale overcollection of domestic communications in excess of the [[United States Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court]]'s authority, but claimed that the acts were unintentional and had since been rectified.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/16/us/16nsa.html |title=Officials Say U.S. Wiretaps Exceeded Law |author=[[Eric Lichtblau]] and [[James Risen]] |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 15, 2009 |access-date=September 5, 2012}}</ref>
In August 2012, ''[[The New York Times]]'' published short documentaries by independent filmmakers titled ''The Program'',<ref>{{cite news |last=Poitras |first=Laura |date=August 22, 2012 |title=The Program |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/23/opinion/the-national-security-agencys-domestic-spying-program.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location= |access-date=August 5, 2016}}</ref> based on interviews with former NSA technical director and [[whistleblower]] [[William Binney (U.S. intelligence official)|William Binney]]. The project had been designed for foreign [[signals intelligence]] (SIGINT) collection but, Binney alleged, after the [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks]], controls that limited unintentional collection of data pertaining to U.S. citizens were removed, prompting concerns by him and others that the actions were illegal and unconstitutional. Binney alleged that the Bluffdale facility was designed to store a broad range of domestic communications for [[data mining]] without warrants.<ref>Lawson, Kent, [http://www.privatewifi.com/what-does-the-nsa-know-about-you/ "What Does the NSA Know About You?"], Private WiFi, August 27, 2012</ref>
Documents leaked to the media in June 2013 described [[PRISM (surveillance program)|PRISM]], a national security [[computer and network surveillance]] program operated by the NSA, as enabling in-depth surveillance on live Internet communications and stored information.<ref name="WaPo1">{{cite news|author1-link=Barton Gellman|last1=Gellman |first1=Barton |author2-link=Laura Poitras|last2=Poitras |first2=Laura |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/investigations/us-intelligence-mining-data-from-nine-us-internet-companies-in-broad-secret-program/2013/06/06/3a0c0da8-cebf-11e2-8845-d970ccb04497_story.html |title=US Intelligence Mining Data from Nine U.S. Internet Companies in Broad Secret Program |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=June 6, 2013 |access-date=June 11, 2013}}</ref><ref name="guardian-snowden-reveal">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jun/09/edward-snowden-nsa-whistleblower-surveillance?CMP=twt_gu |title=Edward Snowden: The Whistleblower Behind Revelations of NSA Surveillance|author=[[Glenn Greenwald|Greenwald, Glenn]]; MacAskill, Ewen |date=June 9, 2013|work=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=June 9, 2013|location=[[Hong Kong]]}}</ref> Reports linked the data center to the NSA's controversial expansion of activities, which store extremely large amounts of data. Privacy and civil liberties advocates raised concerns about the unique capabilities that such a facility would give to intelligence agencies.<ref>{{cite news|title=How the U.S. Uses Technology to Mine More Data More Quickly|author1=James Risen |author2=Eric Lichtblau |lastauthoramp=yes |date=June 8, 2013|access-date=June 11, 2013|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/09/us/revelations-give-look-at-spy-agencys-wider-reach.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Amid Data Controversy, NSA Builds Its Biggest Data Farm|author=Howard Berkes|publisher=National Public Radio|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/06/10/190160772/amid-data-controversy-nsa-builds-its-biggest-data-farm|date=June 10, 2013|access-date=June 11, 2013}}</ref> "They park stuff in storage in the hopes that they will eventually have time to get to it," said James Lewis, a cyberexpert at the [[Center for Strategic and International Studies]], "or that they'll find something that they need to go back and look for in the masses of data." But, he added, "most of it sits and is never looked at by anyone."<ref>Scott Shane and David E. Sanger, [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/01/us/job-title-key-to-inner-access-held-by-snowden.html?hp "Job Title Key to Inner Access Held by Snowden"], ''New York Times'', June 30, 2013</ref>
The UDC was expected to store Internet data, as well as telephone records from the controversial NSA telephone call database, [[MAINWAY]], when it opened in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Phone records could end up at NSA’s Utah Data Center|author=Thomas Burr|work=Salt Lake Tribune|date=June 6, 2013|access-date=June 11, 2013|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/politics/56422716-90/americans-amyspencer-center-court.html.csp}}</ref>
In light of the controversy over the NSA's involvement in the practice of [[mass surveillance in the United States]], and prompted by the [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)|2013 mass surveillance disclosures]] by ex-NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]], the Utah Data Center was hailed by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' as a "symbol of the spy agency's surveillance prowess".<ref name=wsj-7oct13>{{cite news|last=Siobhan Gorman|title=Meltdowns Hobble NSA Data Center|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304441404579119490744478398|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=19 October 2013|quote=The Utah facility, one of the Pentagon's biggest U.S. construction projects, has become a symbol of the spy agency's surveillance prowess, which gained broad attention in the wake of leaks from NSA contractor Edward Snowden. |date=7 October 2013}}</ref>
Binney has said that the facility was built to store recordings and other content of communications, not only for [[metadata]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/government_programs-july-dec13-whistleblowers_08-01/ |title=NSA Collects 'Word for Word' Every Domestic Communication, Says Former Analyst |work=PBS NewsHour |date=1 August 2013 }}</ref>
According to an interview with Snowden, the project was initially known as the Massive Data Repository within NSA, but was renamed to Mission Data Repository due to the former sounding too "creepy".<ref>{{cite web |author=[[James Bamford]] |date=August 2014 |title=Edward Snowden: The Untold Story |publisher=[[Wired (magazine)#Website|Wired]] |url=https://www.wired.com/2014/08/edward-snowden/ }}</ref>
==Structure== [[File:Utah Data Center of the NSA in Bluffdale Utah vector.svg|thumb|left|400px|Utah Data Center area layout]] The planned structure provides 1 to 1.5 million square feet (90,000–140,000 [[Square metre|m<sup>2</sup>]]),<ref name="Kenyon">{{cite news |url=http://defensesystems.com/Articles/2011/01/07/NSA-spy-cyber-intelligence-data-center-Utah.aspx|title=New NSA data center breaks ground on construction -- Defense Systems|last=Kenyon|first=Henry|date=Jan 7, 2011|publisher=Defense Systems|accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref><ref name="cnet">{{cite news|url=http://crave.cnet.co.uk/gadgets/nsa-to-store-yottabytes-in-utah-data-centre-49304118/|title=NSA to store yottabytes in Utah data centre |publisher=[[CNET Networks]]|accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2009/nov/05/whos-in-big-brothers-database/|title=Who’s in Big Brother’s Database? by James Bamford |last=Bamford|first=James|work=[[The New York Review of Books]]|accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref> with 100,000 square feet (9,000 m<sup>2</sup>) of data center space and more than 900,000 square feet (84,000 m<sup>2</sup>) of technical support and administrative space.<ref name=bamford1 /><ref name="Kenyon" /> It is projected to cost $1.5–2 billion.<ref name="deseret1" /><ref name=bamford1 /><ref name="Kenyon" /><ref>{{cite news|title=New NSA center unveiled in budget documents|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/ci_12744661|work=Salt Lake Tribune|publisher=MediaNews Group|author=LaPlante, Matthew D.|date=July 2, 2009|accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=LaPlante, Matthew D.|title=Spies like us: NSA to build huge facility in Utah|url=http://www.sltrib.com/ci_12735293|date=July 2, 2009|publisher=MediaNews Group|work=Salt Lake Tribune|accessdate=2009-07-05}}</ref> A report suggested that it will cost another $2 billion for hardware, software, and maintenance.<ref name="Kenyon" /> The completed facility is expected to require 65 [[megawatt]]s of electricity, costing about $40 million per year.<ref name=bamford1 /><ref name="Kenyon" /> The facility is expected to use 1.7 million gallons (6,435 [[cubic metre|m<sup>3</sup>]]) of water per day.<ref name=water1>{{cite news|url=http://www.ksl.com/?sid=25978926&nid=148|title=New Utah NSA center requires 1.7M gallons of water daily to operate|author=Adams, Andrew|date=July 12, 2013|accessdate=2013-07-25}}</ref> An article by ''[[Forbes]]'' estimates the storage capacity as between 3 and 12 [[exabyte]]s in the near term, based on analysis of unclassified blueprints, but mentions [[Moore's Law]], meaning that advances in technology could be expected to increase the capacity by orders of magnitude in the coming years.<ref name =forbes1 />
Toward the end of the project's construction it was plagued by electrical problems in the form of "massive power surges"<ref name=dcd-10-2013>{{cite web|title=NSA data center 'crippled' by huge power surges|publisher=DatacenterDynamics|date=October 8, 2013|accessdate=April 27, 2014|url=http://www.datacenterdynamics.com/focus/archive/2013/10/nsa-data-center-crippled-huge-power-surges}}</ref> that damaged equipment.<ref name=wsj-7oct13 /> This delayed its opening by a year.<ref name=dcd-10-2013 />

[[Thales Alenia Space|Alcatel Space]] (payload) | launch_mass = {{convert|1326|kg|abbr=on}} | BOL_mass = | landing_mass = | dry_mass = | payload_mass = | dimensions = | power = 3400 | launch_date = {{start date|2003|11|24|06|22|00|7=Z}} | launch_rocket = [[Proton-K]]/[[Blok D|Blok-DM-2M]] | launch_site = [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 81|Site 81/23]] | launch_contractor = | deployment_from = | deployment_date = | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = | destroyed = | last_contact = | recovery_by = | recovery_date = | decay_date = | orbit_reference = [[Geostationary Orbit|GEO]] | orbit_regime = | orbit_longitude = 49°E | orbit_slot = | orbit_semimajor = | orbit_eccentricity = | orbit_periapsis = | orbit_apoapsis = | orbit_inclination = | orbit_period = | orbit_RAAN = | orbit_arg_periapsis = | orbit_mean_anomaly = | orbit_mean_motion = | orbit_repeat = | orbit_velocity = | orbit_epoch = | orbit_rev_number = | apsis = | trans_band = | trans_frequency = 18 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] | trans_bandwidth = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = [[Yamal (satellite constellation)|Yamal Constellation]] | previous_mission = [[Yamal 201]] | next_mission = [[Yamal-300K|Yamal 300K]] | insignia = | insignia_caption = | insignia_alt = | insignia_size = }} '''Yamal 202''' ([[Russian language|Russian]]: {{lang|ru|'''Ямал-202'''}}) was a [[geostationary orbit|geostationary]] [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Gazprom Space Systems|Gazkom]] and built by [[S. P. Korolev Rocket and Space Corporation Energia|RSC Energia]]. It was, along with [[Yamal 201]] the second dual launch of the [[Yamal (satellite constellation)|Yamal]] program and the second iteration of the [[USP (satellite bus)|USP Bus]]. It was a {{convert|1351|kg|abbr=on}} satellite with 4,080W of power (3.4 kW at end of life) on an unpressurized bus. It had eight [[SPT-70]] [[Electrically powered spacecraft propulsion|electric thrusters]] by [[OKB Fakel]] for [[Orbital station-keeping|station keeping]]. Its payload was 18 [[C band (IEEE)|C band]] [[Transponder (satellite communications)|transponders]] supplied by [[Space Systems Loral]]. ==History== During 1997, even before the launch of their first satellites ([[Yamal 101]] and [[Yamal 102]]), [[Gazprom Space Systems|Gazkom]] was planning the second generation. At that time they planned a 24 satellites of the second generation. This extremely aggressive plan was scaled back by 2001 with a plan to launch four 200 series satellites. The first two, [[Yamal 201]] and '''Yamal 202''' would be launched by 2001 and the second pair, [[Yamal 203]] and [[Yamal 204]] by 2004. Yamal 201 and Yamal 203 would be identical and be positioned at the 90°E slot and Yamal 202 and Yamal 204 would also be twins and be positioned at the 49°E slot. Yamal 202 was launched along Yamal 201 November 24, 2003 at 16:2 UTC from [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]] [[Baikonur Cosmodrome Site 81|Site 81/23]] by a [[Proton-K]]/[[Blok D|Blok-DM-2M]] directly to [[geostationary orbit|GEO]]. The launch and satellite deployment was successful and Yamal 201 was commissioned into service. As of July 22, 2016 it is still in service and at 12 years and 8 months it has surpassed its design life of 12.5 years. ==See also== {{Portal |Spaceflight}} * [[Yamal 201]] – Satellite that was launched together with Yamal 202. * [[Yamal (satellite constellation)|Yamal]] – Communication satellite family operated by Gazprom Space Systems. * [[Gazprom Space Systems]] – Satellite communication division of the [[Russia]]n oil giant [[Gazprom]]. * [[USP (satellite bus)|USP Bus]] – The satellite bus on which Yamal 202 is based. * [[S. P.
